Class CollectionTimer

  • java.lang.Object
    • CollectionTimer
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ListTimer, QueueTimer

    public abstract class CollectionTimer
extends java.lang.Object
    Abstract class that is to be extended by classes that wish to time the performance of some data structure. Contrary to what the name implies, it is not enforced that the data structures that are timed implement the Collection interface. The data structure will need to support insertion of Integer objects.

    • Constructor Summary

      CollectionTimer()
      Default constructor.
      CollectionTimer(long elemGenSeed)
      Constructor that creates a CollectionTimer instance with a random object generator with the specified seed.

    • Method Detail

      • insert

        public void insert(int amount)
        Inserts a specified number of Integer objects into the data structure. This method assumes that the underlying data structure supports the insertion of the required number of objects. If such is not the case, then (depending on the implementation), an exception may be thrown.
        Parameters:
        amount - number of objects to insert

      • extract

        public boolean extract(int amount)
        Removes a specified number of objects from the data structure.
        Parameters:
        amount - number of objects to remove
        Returns:
        true if sufficient elements were present, false otherwise.

      • time

        public long time()
        Times a sequence of operations on the underlying data structure. This method performs the mutations defined by DEFAULT_MUTATIONS. Timing takes place by subtracting the number of milliseconds since the UNIX epoch before and after the required operations have taken place. Note that the actual accuracy is platform dependant and may be influenced by other processes running on the host machine.
        Returns:
        elapsed time in milliseconds
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_MUTATIONS

      • time

        public long time(int[] mutations)
        Times a specified sequence of operations on the underlying data structure. This method performs the given operations in successive order, as they occur in the given array. Insertions are specified by a positive number, removal of objects are denoted by a negative value. If mutations equals null, then the default mutations as defined by DEFAULT_MUTATIONS are performed. Timing takes place by subtracting the number of milliseconds since the UNIX epoch before and after the required operations have taken place. Note that the actual accuracy is platform dependant and may be influenced by other processes running on the host machine.
        Parameters:
        mutations - integer array defining which successive permutations should be performed
        Returns:
        elapsed time in milliseconds
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_MUTATIONS

      • addElement

        public abstract void addElement(java.lang.Integer elem)
        Adds the given object to the data structure.
        Parameters:
        elem - object to add to the data structure

      • removeElement

        public abstract void removeElement()
                            throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        Removes some object from the data structure.

        QUESTION: "How will the implementation of removeElement() affect the performance of the different ADTs?"

        ANSWER: For ADTs based on the List class the method used is removing elements at the end. This has the best performance since if one would remove an element at any other index all the elements coming after the removed one would have to be moved one index to the front.

        For ADTs based on the Queue class this is the other way around. The method used to remove elements is poll(), which returns the element at the start. If one would opt to remove any other element, just as with the List class, the elements coming before that element have to be moved one index.

        When removeElement is implemented this way, both classes have "optimal" performance and can be comapred in a realistic way, which is why we chose to implement it in this way.

        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If no element can be removed from the underlying data structure

      • getSize

        public abstract int getSize()
        Determines the size of the data structure that is being timed.

        public abstract boolean isEmpty()
